Title: Non-intrusive musculoskeletal disorders risk assessment towards an integration in human operators’ Digital Twins
Authors: Nicolas Murcia, A. Mohafid, O. Cardin
Abstract summary: The paper presents a method to assess musculoskeletal disorder risk in human operators' digital twins for non-repetitive operations.

Title: MAINTAINING ENGAGEMENT IN LONG-TERM INTERVENTIONS WITH RELATIONAL AGENTS
Authors: T. Bickmore, Daniel Schulman, Langxuan Yin
Abstract summary: The paper discusses issues in maintaining user engagement with virtual agents over long-term interactions, but does not address the long-term effectiveness and adaptability of human-digital twin partnerships.

Title: Digital Twins Generated by Artificial Intelligence in Personalized Healthcare
Authors: Marian Łukaniszyn, Łukasz Majka, Barbara Grochowicz, Dariusz Mikołajewski, Aleksandra Kawala-Sterniuk
Abstract summary: Digital twins generated by AI can support personalized healthcare through simulated clinical trials, disease prediction, and remote patient monitoring.

Title: Feeding the Coffee Habit: A Longitudinal Study of a Robo-Barista
Authors: Mei Yii Lim, David A. Robb, Bruce W. Wilson, Helen F. Hastie
Venue: IEEE International Symposium on Robot and Human Interactive Communication
Abstract summary: This paper is not directly relevant to the query about open research questions regarding long-term effectiveness and adaptability of human-digital twin partnerships. It presents a longitudinal study of user interactions with a Robo-Barista, examining factors associated with usefulness, adaptability and likeability.

Title: Tools and methods for Human-Autonomy Teaming: Contributions to cognitive state monitoring and system adaptation
Abstract summary: The paper explores methods for monitoring human cognitive states and adapting human-autonomy teaming to make autonomous systems better teammates.

Title: A Long-form Research Program in Human Behavior, Ecology, and Culture
Abstract summary: This paper does not directly address the long-term effectiveness and adaptability of human-digital twin partnerships, but rather proposes a long-form research program to study human behavior, ecology, and culture.

Title: Workshop on Longitudinal Human-Robot Teaming
Authors: J. D. Greeff, Bradley Hayes, M. Gombolay, Matt Johnson, Mark Antonius Neerincx, J. Diggelen, Melissa Cefkin, Ivana Kruijff-Korbayová
Venue: IEEE/ACM International Conference on Human-Robot Interaction
Abstract summary: The workshop aims to address research questions on enabling effective and safe long-term human-robot teamwork.

Title: The digital platform: a research agenda
Authors: M. D. Reuver, C. Sørensen, Rahul C. Basole
Abstract summary: This paper does not directly address the long-term effectiveness and adaptability of human-digital twin partnerships, but rather proposes a research agenda for digital platforms in general.
